page.title: List of premiers of New Brunswick

revisions.rev:
{{Refimprove|date=March 2011}} The [[Canada|Canadian]] province of [[New Brunswick]] was a British [[crown colony]] before it joined [[Canada]] in 1867.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-11-09|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/confederation/023001-2110-e.html|title=Canadian Confederation|date=2005-05-02|publisher=Library and Archives Canada |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080622201545/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/confederation/023001-2110-e.html |archivedate = 2008-06-22}} It had a system of [[responsible government]] beginning in 1854, and has kept its own legislature to deal with provincial matters.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-11-09|url=http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/confederation/023001-2974-e.html|title=Responsible Government|date=2005-05-02|publisher=Library and Archives Canada |archiveurl = http://web.archive.org/web/20080621130920/http://www.collectionscanada.gc.ca/confederation/023001-2974-e.html |archivedate = 2008-06-21}} New Brunswick has a unicameral [[Westminster System|Westminster-style]] [[parliamentary government]], in which the Premier is the leader of the party that controls the most seats in the [[Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick|Legislative Assembly]]. The Premier is New Brunswick's [[head of government]], and the [[Queen of Canada]] is its [[head of state]] and is represented by the [[Lieutenant Governor of New Brunswick]]. The Premier picks a cabinet from the elected members to form the [[Executive Council of New Brunswick]], and presides over that body.{{cite web|accessdate=2008-11-09|url=http://www.gnb.ca/legis/publications/tradition/legtrad4-e.asp|title=The Legislative Process |publisher=Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick }} Members are first elected to the legislature during [[List of New Brunswick general elections|general elections]]. General elections must be conducted every five years from the date of the last election, but the Premier may ask for early dissolution of the Legislative Assembly. An election may also take place if the governing party loses the confidence of the legislature by the defeat of a supply bill or tabling of a confidence motion. New Brunswick has had 36 individuals serve as government leaders. The province had five individuals as leaders while a colony, and 31 individuals after Canadian Confederation, of which two were from the [[Confederation Party]], 11 from the [[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick]], 15 from the [[New Brunswick Liberal Association]], one from the [[Anti-Confederation Party]], and seven with unofficial party affiliations. ==Premiers of New Brunswick== {{legend2||[[Confederation Party]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|cornflowerblue|[[Progressive Conservative Party of New Brunswick]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|lightcoral|[[New Brunswick Liberal Association]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|sandybrown|[[Anti-Confederation Party]]|border=1px solid #AAAAAA}} {{legend2|gainsboro|Unofficial affiliation|border=1px solid #aaa}} {| class="wikitable" |- !colspan="3"| Premier

Present |align="center"| [[57th New Brunswick Legislative Assembly|57th]] | [[New Brunswick general election, 2010|Elected September 27, 2010]] |} * The New Brunswick practice is to count George E. King as the 2nd and 4th Premier, making David Alward the 32nd Premier.{{cite web|title=Shawn Graham Bios|url=http://www1.gnb.ca/legis/bios1/bio-e.asp?IDNo=130&version=e|publisher=Legislative Assembly of New Brunswick|accessdate=2011-03-19|date=2010-08-26}} ==Living former Premiers== {{As of|2011|3}}, five former Premiers are alive, the oldest being [[Ray Frenette]] (1997–1998, born 1935). The most recent former Premier to die was [[Louis Robichaud]] (1960–1970), on January 6, 2005. The most recently-serving Premier to die was [[Richard Hatfield]] (1970–1987), on April 26, 1991. {| class="wikitable" !Name!!Term!!Date of birth |- |[[Frank McKenna]] |1987–1997 |{{birth date and age|1948|1|19}} |- |[[Ray Frenette]] |1997–1998 |{{birth date and age|1935|4|16}} |- |[[Camille ThÃ©riault]] |1998–1999 |{{birth date and age|1955|2|25}} |- |[[Bernard Lord]] |1999–2006 |{{birth date and age|1965|9|27}} |- |[[Shawn Graham]] |2006–2010 |{{birth date and age|1968|2|22}} |} ==See also== * [[Leader of the Opposition (New Brunswick)]] == References == ;General {{refbegin}} * {{cite web|accessdate=2008-11-09|url=http://www.cbc.ca/nbvotes2006/features/feature1-bythenumbers.html|title=New Brunswick by the numbers |publisher=CBC|date=2006-08-25 }} * {{cite web|accessdate=2008-11-09|url=http://www.gnb.ca/legis/leglibbib/special_projects/premiers.asp|title=Premiers of New Brunswick |publisher=The Legislative Library of New Brunswick }} * {{cite book |last=Doyle |first=Arthur T. |title=Elections in New Brunswick, 1784-1984 |year=1984 |publisher=Brunswick Press |location=Fredericton |isbn=0888383916}} {{refend}} ;Specific {{reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://www.gnb.ca/0089/Index-e.asp New Brunswick Office of the Premier] {{NBPremiers}} {{New Brunswick politics}} {{Canadian First Ministers}} {{featured list}} {{DEFAULTSORT:List Of Premiers Of New Brunswick}} [[Category:Lists of Canadian first ministers|New Brunswick]] [[Category:Premiers of New Brunswick|*]] [[Category:New Brunswick-related lists|Premiers]] [[de:Liste der Premierminister von New Brunswick]] [[es:Anexo:Primer ministro de Nueva Brunswick]] [[fr:Premier ministre du Nouveau-Brunswick]]
